title: How to Strip Cloth Diapers

steps.headline: Wash the diapers before stripping them.
steps.description: It’s important to start with clean cloth diapers, preferably ones that have been dried as well. Wash your cloth diapers as you normally would to prepare them for the stripping process.

steps.headline: Fill a basin halfway full with hot water.
steps.description: Pour the water into a top-loader washing machine, bathtub, or regular container. Make sure the water is super hot, preferably between 120–125 °F (49–52 °C), so that it will work properly.

steps.headline: Add a stripping agent to the water of your choosing.
steps.description: Select an additive like RLR laundry treatment, Mighty Bubbles, or your own at-home concoction. Pour the stripping agent into the water, following the package instructions if applicable. Create a DIY additive by combining 3 US tbsp (44 ml) each of washing soda, Borax, and Calgon. Pour half a cup of laundry detergent into the water too for added strength.

steps.headline: Soak the cloth diapers in the water for roughly 6 hours.
steps.description: Soak the diapers overnight, if desired, but try not to soak them for more than 8 hours. Soak the diapers for at least 2 hours, with an ideal time between 4 and 6 hours. Once the water has cooled completely, take the diapers out.

steps.headline: Agitate the cloth diapers to ensure the minerals are being removed.
steps.description: If you’re using a top-loader, run the cycle every few minutes by starting the washing machine and stopping it to get the diapers and water moving around. If you’re using a tub or container, use a large spoon to mix the diapers around. Stirring the diapers occasionally will help release unwanted minerals. If the water becomes darker, don’t worry! This is natural.

steps.headline: Remove the diapers from the water and wring them out.
steps.description: Drain the water from the container or top-loader and take out the cloth diapers. Wring each one individually to try to get as much excess water out as possible. Set the diapers aside, as they’ll be going into the washing machine to be rinsed.

steps.headline: Rinse the diapers in cold water until you no longer see any bubbles.
steps.description: Place all of the cloth diapers in the washing machine without any soap or stripping agents. Run a cold cycle, checking to see if you spot any soap bubbles once the cycle is finished. If you do see bubbles, continue with another cycle to rinse them out. You may have to rinse out the diapers as many as 3-5 times.

steps.headline: Dry the cloth diapers in the sunlight, if possible.
steps.description: Hang the cloth diapers on a clothesline outside, or position them on a clothes rack next to a window so that they can feel the sun. This will help them dry quickly and efficiently.

methods.name: Determining if Diapers Need to Be Stripped

steps.headline: Look for diaper cream residue in the diapers.
steps.description: If you use diaper cream on your baby frequently, it’s common for a film to stick to the cloth diapers from the cream that’s difficult to remove. If you spot this film, strip the diapers to remove it.

steps.headline: Smell the diapers to see if they have an odor after being washed.
steps.description: If you’ve cleaned the cloth diapers and they’re still emitting a strong smell, this is a sign that they need to be stripped. Give the cloth diapers a quick sniff once you’ve washed them to decide whether they smell fresh and clean or smelly.

steps.headline: Inspect the diapers to see if they’re leaking while being used.
steps.description: If you’ve noticed that your baby’s diaper hasn’t been absorbing like it should or frequently leaks, this might indicate the diaper’s material is being affected by the minerals in the water. Strip the cloth diapers to help improve the absorbency.

steps.headline: Determine if you’ve been washing the diapers in untreated hard water.
steps.description: Hard water is water that has a high mineral content, which is something to avoid when washing diapers. If you have hard water, there are things you can use to treat it, such as vinegar or rinse aids, to help soften it. Find out if you have hard water by adding soap to a bottle of water, shaking it up, and checking for bubbles.
